_header: What is he this that cometh so bright
Subjects: Christ, sufferings of; scripture, paraphrases of; dialogues, Christ and man
_description: Christ comes with bloody Garments — three couplets

BLHar7322.Transcription:
Wat is he þis þat comet so brithWit blodi cloþes al
                    bedithrespondentes superiores dixeruntHe is boþe god and
                    manswilc ne sawe never nanfor adamis sinne he suffrede dedand
                    þerfore is his robe so red
BLHar7322.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Political, Religious and Love Poems, from Lambeth MS. 306 and other
                sources.
EETS
         o.s. 15 (1866); repr. 1962; rev. ed. 1903: 231; rev. ed. 259.
Woolf,  Rosemary. 
             The English Religious Lyric in the Middle Ages.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1968: 200.

WorcF126.Transcription:
Wat ys he þat comeþ so brythwyt blody cloþes al
                    bydithHe ys God ful of mythþat man bycam for vs to ffythFor
                    oure sennes he was dedand þerfor ys hyts robe so red
WorcF126.Note: Second couplet varies significantly; written as prose.
